data.longTitle: Our Local Climate - Right Here, Right Now!

content.contentBeforeFold:
At the north end of the lake, a raft over the deepest part of Elbow Lake (just under 9 m or about 29 ft in depth) supports one of seven climate monitoring stations located across QUBS properties with one additional site within Thousand Islands National Park on the St. Lawrence River.

Stations are positioned to compare lakes both within the same latitude, as well as lakes across different latitudes. (Credit: SutronWIN)

From the raft, the Elbow Lake station monitors ambient air temperature; relative humidity (RH); wind speed, direction and gusts; barometric pressure; and water temperature both near the surface (1.1 m depth) and 2 metres below. In addition to these climate data, the Elbow Lake station gathers water temperature data below the orange buoy at 15 depth intervals ranging from 0.25 m to 9 m, and measures dissolved oxygen at 1 m depth. Land-based gauges monitor precipitation from the adjacent shoreline, and record soil temperature 5 cm and 15 centimetres below the surface.

Measurements are collected frequently, enabling researchers to track changes in local climate in real-time over time intervals as short as 15 minutes. Climate data are relayed via satellite to a central server, where they are immediately available online for use by researchers worldwide! In time we will have these data available in real-time on a screen in the lodge. Data from these stations are being used to study changes in local climate and their influence on ecosystems and individual species.
